Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Whole Ecosystem Experiments on Early Warnings for Regime Shifts to Cyanobacteria in Lakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
While nature often changes slowly, sometimes large changes occur fast. Fisheries collapse, rangelands decline, and invasive species expand rapidly often with high costs to human society. Big changes in ecological systems are difficult to forecast but recent theoretical studies and experiments indicate that they are preceded by early warnings. These early warnings are like economic indicators and can be detected in environmental variables that can be measured frequently. In principle when early warning indicators are detected actions can either avert unwanted changes, like responding to a check engine light in a car, or help minimize risk, like responding to a tornado siren. This project will test the potential to avoid unwanted changes in lakes by detecting early warning signals. Several lakes will be experimentally fertilized with nutrients to create the potential for massive growths of algae. Early warning signals will be detected by continuously monitoring the lakes with modern electronic sensors. In a further experiment, the researchers will respond to signals that indicate impending changes and stop the nutrient additions to one lake in an attempt to avoid algae proliferating to nuisance levels. Treatments to the other lakes will continue so that all possible responses are included.

This project will determine if methods for detecting early warnings signals can be developed. The findings from this study will be extended to a network of researchers who have established continuous measurement systems on lakes throughout the world. If successful, the results should be widely applicable for the management of a range of natural systems, not only lakes. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students and contribute to teaching materials for courses at universities in Virginia and Wisconsin, as well as advanced special topics courses at the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies in New York.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Whole Ecosystem Experiments on Early Warnings for Regime Shifts to Cyanobacteria in Lakes

 

While nature often changes slowly, sometimes large changes occur fast.  Fisheries collapse, rangelands decline, and invasive species expand rapidly often with high costs to human society.  Big changes in ecological systems are difficult to forecast but recent theoretical studies and experiments indicate that they are preceded by early warnings.  These early warnings can be detected in environmental variables, if these variables can be measured at high frequency.  In principle when early warning indicators are detected actions can either avert unwanted changes (like responding to a check engine light in a car) or help minimize risk (like responding to a tornado siren).  This project made direct tests of the potential to avoid unwanted changes in lakes by detecting early warnings.  Two small lakes were slowly and continuously fertilized with nutrients thus creating massive growths of algae.  Early warnings were detected by continuously monitoring the lakes with modern sensors on rafts that made measurements of multiple variables at 5 to 10 minute intervals for the entire season.  During the first two years, we examined the potential of the high frequency measurements and the statistical programs we developed to predict ahead of time the oncoming algal blooms. After we were confident that the early warning signals successfully predicted the bloom, in the third year, we responded to early warning “alarms” and ceased the nutrient additions in an attempt to avoid algae proliferating to nuisance levels.  These alarms were predetermined changes in indicator statistics in the high frequency data of chlorophyll (a pigment in all algae), phycocyanin (a pigment in blue-green algae) and dissolved oxygen (which is produced during photosynthesis). We were successful in stopping the predicted algal bloom.  

The approaches  successfully tested in this project could potentially be widely used to manage a range of natural systems and living resources.  Further, our findings and approaches are now being used by a network of researchers who have established continuous measurement systems on lakes throughout the world in the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON).  The project  trained three graduate and 14 undergraduate students and contribute to teaching materials for courses at the universities of Virginia and Wisconsin as well as advanced special topics course at the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies.
